comments.body: (Changed title to summarize post and make it shorter/easier to locate.)
there is a white list
This isn't possible. Maliciously modded clients tell servers that they are just vanilla clients.

Were having the same issue on Bedrock realms, people using Modded add on's and texture packs from X ray to super man creative options. Realms and servers lack the ability to add staff without turning on cheats, They must have access to the server database ( High trust level) to even deal with them on a server. There is  No Spectator mode to catch players in the act, as well as no way for staff other then a realm owner to remove them or trolls that change their good vs evil aspects of game play when the owner is not online and grief entire worlds.

I've always wondered this too, but on the other hand, Mojang aren't really responsible for the servers, and they have a game to develop....

Apparently they are looking to implement 2-factor authentication, which should cut down on cheating, too.
I was going to recommend this but I found this thread!
Thank you for using search! :)
I think this should be toggleable - there are some servers like 2b2t where hacked clients are allowed and are part of the game, but for other servers, this would be great, other than that, I agree.

Could you change the title so that it has the word ”hack” in it too?
I searched for ”hack” and it didn’t show me this thread and therefore, I made a duplicate.
no
Yeah, I've had a problem with people using unfair modifications on my bedrock dedicated server... It would be nice to have a anti-cheat!

Mojang is not responsible for the cheater problem on Java. Minecraft Java Edition is practically a community edition and gives so much power to the player. If servers wanna make a client-side anticheat, they can, but Mojang is not obligated to these independent servers. Now Bedrock Edition is another story and I made a suggestion for that; however, you must understand Minecraft, especially Java edition, is a game where you can do what you want. Players can make cheats and server owners can combat them.

Makes the whole gaming system worthless without central control, no excuses. When my 2 Realm accounts are finished I will be putting Minecraft to rest. Time to move on to a game where hackers and cheaters can be controlled. Even the Glitches like duping that has never been addressed makes the game worthless as far as any server Realm or not worthless.

 

Client to client for family members only, the game can be fun but that's as far as this game goes. Add in "friends" and there goes any trust let alone the use of exploits that are used. What are the traders in the villages for? Heck just du what you need, why mine or farm, simply set up an auto farm.

Like I said  GAME WORTLESS unless used by family only.

Mojang is not responsible for cheaters/hackers. It should be the servers' responsibility if there are hackers. Also the problem with client-side anticheats is someone could simply mod the game and make it look legit when they are cheating. Every anarchy server and their players would hate this.
Anticheat can't be clientside because hacked clients can just remove it
Yes, this should actually be ”Vanilla server anti-cheat”.

I think There Should Be An Option In Both Minecraft Bedrock And Java that Allows You To Enable Certain Cheat Detection's Like Detect When An Item Is Enchanted Past Normal Or Someone Is Going To Fast And Other Stuff Like That

I think that instead of a client-side anticheat, maybe add something that will send an additional packet to the server stating whether or not the player is using a vanilla client, and let the server handle this by itself. This would be useful for servers like 2b2t where hacking is allowed and encouraged. 

Please note that I am aware that hacked client developers would figure out a way to break this, but isn't the exact same thing happening with server-side anticheats?
The anticheat might think people are using speed hacks, but they might just have had a speed potion.
idc if this was added, but should be toggleable for realms and servers.

I was talking to one of my admins about this, and the main problem is legality. To test for the client a player is using in that way, youd end up accessing more than just client info. Ie. Personal information. Mojang might still be working on the game, but microsoft runs the show and definitely wouldnt allow such a module to run through their servers. What they need to do is give us the ability to clear enchant levels and clear actual illegal items. You cant clear players of end_portals, water/lava tiles or any other hacked blocks, even tho they're litterally in the game and that's just absurd if you ask me

One thing I don't understand about this conversation. Is the anticheat about forcing other people to stop cheating, or send a notification about someone cheated and an option to report it to the server owner? I means detection of other player and sending notification is possible right? I believe lots of players are looking forward for this mod since it would be very useful.

On Minecraft Realms they should at least add something to be able to identify and remove illegal items, like sharpness 32767 on a sword and stop third party apps like toolbox from spawning items. I understand others hacks like flying, kill aura, etc. are hard to combat but they should at least remove illegal items and item spawning that's all I'm asking for. Oh and also remove the beehive exploit; that's the worst!!!
Microsoft and Mojang won't add this
woooooow!!

While I, personally, may or may not make use of all or any of these options, I feel they would offer BDS administrators more control over their server environment, as well as potentially enhancing the quality of experience for the players on that server. Additionally, some of the suggested settings may be useful in troubleshooting issues such as lag.

To that end, here are a couple of other options for the server.properties file that I imagine would be welcome by BDS admins:

  • allow-nether - Allow players to construct Nether portals to travel to the Nether
  • allow-end - Allow players to travel to the End
  • generate-structures - Defines whether or not structures such as villages are generated in the world
  • spawn-<mob type> - Defines whether or not certain types of mobs (animals, monsters, NPC's) can spawn in the world (perhaps this could be implemented as a single allow-spawns option with a value of either "all" or a pipe-delimited or JSON-formatted list)
  • logging-level - Provides options for the verbosity of logs from bedrock_server.exe

*Where available, I took the descriptions from the Minecraft Wiki and condensed them to fit within the posting limit.

We need too :
Like java
/Ban
/Ban-ip [or]
/Pardon (optional name /unban )
/Pardon-ip
/Whitelist {add|remove }
/Whitelist list (show players on whitelist)
/Whitelist {on|off}
And specific to bedrock
/Ban-os (ban a type of os)
/Ban-ipt (ban a type of input (controller/screen touch/keyboard)
But if a player are In the whitelist he can ignore the ban OS and ban input

There should be a configuration that enables coordinates. Something like the statement below would suffice:
display-coordinates=true/false

394414535651 - Thanks for the support. I agree that those commands would be tremendously helpful to have available, however they aren't "configuration settings", per se. They could interact with the configuration settings outlined above - for example, the /ban and /pardon commands could add or remove users to/from the blacklist I referred to.

What I'm proposing here are settings preparing the BDS environment before the server is launched - i.e, should the server use or ignore the blacklist (I imagine a new blacklist.json file would be necessary)? Again, the commands you mentioned would "tie in" to these settings and possibly be able to modify them at run time, but might require a "reload" and/or server restart to apply the changes.

Again, while I may or may not make use of them, I can understand wanting to disallow clients using a certain OS/platform or input method. Perhaps create a setting in the server.properties file as allowed-platforms/allowed-inputs where the values are either a pipe-delimited list or simply "all".

One thing to note: The whitelist commands you mentioned are mostly already implemented in the console with the exception of whitelist {on|off}. whitelist {add|remove} updates the whitelist.json file in the server's directory (which, as I stated above, I'd like to be able to change with a command-line argument). The whitelist list command outputs a JSON string to the console that includes the players currently in the whitelist.json file.
365668671752 - Thanks for the support. I can't believe I didn't think of that option myself. An excellent addition to the list.

Another option to consider is based on the BDS-1094 bug report regarding the additional, "random" ports that are opened at BDS startup. I'm not sure what this feature would be since I'm not sure what the intended purpose of these "extra" ports is, but having a setting to provide some control over this would be a good addition to the server.properties file.

I really need enable-rcon support - my server goes down every night for a few minutes to perform backups, and I really want a way to inform my users five or ten minutes before that happens.
I have the Bedrock Dedicated Server running, but I can't find a way for the server to create scheduled backups?  Is this possible or would I need to add a script?
Hardcore could be made a gamerule. https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/24287009192589--gamerule-hardcore
Chat reporting should be completely removed
either have it as a toggle or just flat out remove it

Agreed. If it were toggleable, servers with built-in moderation could go without it, and anyone joining a server with it disabled would just have to check something saying they're over 13 or 16, depending on the age they want to go with.

I am literally too afraid of someone using the gaslighting or similar mods to allow any strangers on my realm. How am I supposed to grow my community on my half-decade-plus old realm when I'm terrified that incompetently-implemented "feature" could wind up costing me it all?! Genuinely considering canceling my realms subscription and switching to a normal server so I can use mods to disable chat reporting from functioning. Safety first, after all! You can't implement a system that dangerous when it's so easily exploitable!

Downright remove the system, there is already a warning saying servers may contain unrated content so there is no reason to have this, if we want moderation tools we'll use the already refined ones made by the community that we have control of
this system should be wipe out from the minecraft but if you can't do this, just add Toggle Chat Reporting

Chat report is a good thing, at least the idea and just for smaller servers, big servers that already has moderation and /report feature don't need the minecraft chat report at all. But for smaller servers this can be usefull. But the sentence is too great, chat report should ban you from the server and ask to mods if it should be permanent or not. Otherwise it's just dumb if you've been banned when you haven't done anything
It should be a line in the server.properties file you have to access when hosting a server. And it should be an option when you start a LAN server.
the sad part is as good as it would be to toggle it they’re never gonna do it :(
I think ALL server moderators don't like this feature
Minecraft dosnt care sadly.

Definitely should be ENTIRELY optional for server owners, down to allowing banned players to join servers who opt to allow them. Control of third-party servers and their players should remain SOLELY in the hands of the server's agents and team, as we foot the hosting fees and payment to moderation teams where applicable.

This system is deeply flawed and is not fit for a space where there is such a wide scope and sequence outside of bedrock partnered servers. I can see this applying to Realms and Partnered Servers, but this system is not sufficient in its current state for the goals it wishes to achieve.
I also want this feature for my nephews. I've been waiting for Realms to come to Xbone but the lack of this feature makes it unusable.
I would like to actually be able to play on servers on my phone and I have my privacy settings to were I can play whatever with other people and yet I can’t use servers

Please let me play on a server please!

"This very bad as most of the servers are not appropriate for children and contain inappropriate language, behaviors, and could include predatory people."

 

Oh, it's not like there's a chat filter that's way too aggressive, or Mineplex deleted half the games on their network so they could focus on the Bedrock server, including reports, muting filter bypassers, etc.

Microsoft has DESTROYED multiplayer functionality in Bedrock. Before I was able to let my kids play on a local server I created on my LAN, while blocking them from accessing public servers.

Now, for some asinine reason, Microsoft thought it was a good idea to combine both.

This is beyond common sense. How THICK can one be?

This a bad idea to be honest..

Fun fact: there is a chat filter and real people moderate these servers to keep the content family-friendly.

Also, the "featured servers" are official servers that Mojang has allowed to be there and have special perks and etc.
servers are a part of the game i have played for 5 years and only a few servers have had bad stuff why would you block all of them
no just mo

This is word for word the feature request I wanted to write. A simple setting protected by a pin code to hide the Servers tab. If Mojang doesn’t want the responsibility of having parental control features within the game, then just have a setting to hide the tab even if it’s not protected by a code, that would be enough for now.

I bought a Nintendo Switch this Christmas with the sole purpose of playing Minecraft with my niece and nephew who have been fans of this game for a while. I live in a foreign country and have been missing them growing up so I thought this was a great opportunity to stay connected.

Never would have I imagined that the game most popular among children doesn’t get parental controls right.

I know that I can disable chatting with strangers on their accounts but you have to understand that some of us don’t want children to interact with strangers online at all. I just want them to be able to connect to realms with friends, so easily accessing the public servers is a definite No.

If someone at Microsoft or Mojang sees this. Please raise the priority of this issue. Difficulty is not high and it would have a huge impact.

Thank you!

This remains an important flaw in Bedrock.

Yes, there are chat filters and yes, most servers are moderated appropriately.

Those who are satisfied with that level of protection will simply not use the feature we are suggesting.

But providing this added safeguard will boost subscriptions for Realms since the lack of it is one reason disappointed parents drop.

100% the whole point of the private Realm is to keep the kids in a contained environment with only approved (KNOWN TO ME) friends.  We need to be able to keep Realms but remove the Featured Servers its not safe

This is an absolutely needed feature. My six-year-old was exposed to racial slurs and depictions of genitalia on a "featured" sever. I want him to be able to play with his brothers, but do not want him, or his brothers for that matter, on public servers. I feel like this is a reasonable expectation. The "all-or-nothing" approach to multiplayer is absolutely insufficient.

I don't understand why this doesn't have 1000 votes.

I just got a new realms, but now I think I'm already gonna cancel my subscription. You can't step away from your keyboard for 5 minutes. It's super annoying and unnecessary.

I don't see why a compromise can't be met. Like the default is x amount of minutes, but you can change it to a maximum x amount of hours. Something that makes both parties happy.

Allows players to step away for a minute, of leave the game running for a while and still have ample time to get back and resume.

An example for me is I help someone with minecraft who streams and I like to be in the world to help, but I also type up a list of instructions for him to read. Having a realms would make much more convenient for the both of us than it being hosted on an xbox. But that convenience gets taken away when he can't read for minute or interact with stream without getting booted.

If you hold right click on a door or a trapdoor and press F3+T, then let go when the mojang screen pops up, you should be opening and closing the trapdoor without pressing anything on your keyboard. This should allow you to go AFK without getting kicked out, becuase the game doesn't realize that you're AFK since you're opening a trapdoor.

THISS. It's nice to have your own dedicated server, but sadly friends that play on Switch or Xbox can't join. Maybe to fix the "safety" issue or whatever, they can give a prompt before joining that says to only join servers that you trust, and maybe some warnings about joining random servers. Java has been able to do it for yeaars now, it would be nice if we finally got the ability to be TRULY cross platform in this regard as well.

This would be beneficial to PC players that can host worlds to other friends that can join and not worry about the limitations of the console or the realm hosting. Also that would allow for more ram to be put in to the server fixing a ton of lag issue for others who want a stable game. I highly suggest this be added, I would hope safety issues wouldn't be a problem for people who want to play on the Dedicated servers, i don't see why Console players couldn't join, PC people don't have safety issues with it.

You then could enable friends only, friends of friends, or invite only in the server.proporties.

This is not a good idea, if you want simple servers pay for realms. It would significantly decrease security if it would even be possible. Allowing something to set up incoming connections without you manually setting up port forwarding would be a very bad idea. If your not comfortable setting up a dedicated server find a friend who is, or buy a realm.

Strongly disagree.

Maybe running a server is so complicated because new players aren't supposed to go create servers? If you're looking for a quick way to play with your friends, you can use Realms. Second best option would be to invite your friends onto your world through Xbox Live (Bedrock only). Your world will however not be always online. Lastly, if you wanna play with your buddies on Java, you can give Aternos a shot. But just like the second option, the server won't be always online.

And if you wanna make a biggy big server, then you should honestly invest your time into researching how to properly moderate and set one up. Just imagine the chaos if creating huge 1000+ player, always online servers was as easy as clicking a button.
Hey great idea, but like the MCgeek guy said there should be security enhancement like anti-hacks.

Definitely add this. I have a the official dedicated Bedrock Server software on my laptop. I cannot join it from my Switch though because there is no button to “Add a Server.” It doesn’t show it as a LAN game either.

Allow switch users to join dedicated servers. After all they are Minecraft certified servers.

For anyone seeing this: set your Nintendo Switch internet settings to have DNS on manual, set DNS 1 to 104.238.130.180 and DNS 2 to 1.1.1.1, this will let you join servers other than the official ones.

This needs to be done.

whatever the bullshit reason is, get passed it. im furious that i cant connect to a server being hosted on my own damn network with a game i purchased. 50%(at least) of what makes this game worth anything is being able to run our own private servers without hassle.

Absolutely I greee with it. There is a workaround to add a server to Nintendo switch by using a strange DNS server to show the internal server list. But it is extremely dangerous if the DNS server is poisoned. There should be a secure way to add any server for switch users.

Adding this to older versions would cause a version change and then no longer applying to those versions. I get that servers like Hypixel have a variety of versions supported, but Mojang doesn't officially support it. I don't think they should update older versions for anything besides critical security concerns, because then the version isn't the same version anymore. If either a client or server sent an unsupported packet to each other, they both crashed.

I think they should just add it to major versions and at least the latest versions.
And as the earlier comment say that they both crash due to unsupported packet maybe like Hypixel did some tweaking to support all these versions on the same server maybe Hypixel or Mojang can do that for the packets as well. Also maybe Mojang can provide the option to whether to use transfer packets or not. 
I don't know much about these technical things but I hope if Mojang and Hypixel can do something about this everyone would be really happy but at last it depends on Mojang. So Mojang I request that the idea of adding transfer packet to older or newer or both version should be considered. 
Thank you!

Transfer packet? Yeah!
For all versions? No...

It cannot be considered to update 6-years old versions of Minecraft JE just for the sake of some servers... If they want to use the transfer packet then, either they update the whole server to the latest version (which would be pretty good in fact, they could make use of all the new features of Minecraft), or only use this packet for the players with an up-to-date game.

Players from far-away countries will then have a choice: not to update and still have large ping, or update and benefit from it.
Minecraft must do it MUST

I live in asia and whenever im not hypixel i get upwards of 150 ping so i dont really stand a chance against people from the us. Adding Transfer packets will be a game changer.

I agree with most if not all comments in this feedback vote. they should make transfer packets and add them to the game. they shouldn't do this to all versions since that would be too much work and not that useful but adding them to the popular versions and newer versions would indeed be good. as a hypixel player i get 150-250ms and that isnt really an optimal ping. especially for the past 2 days i cant play hypixel because when i join and try to go into a game or do anything the server doesnt respond. i get teleported into limbo or timed out. another way this end is that i keep clicking with the game menu on the skyblock teleport npc until i get teleported, the game menu opens where i spam the skyblock logo or get put into, you guessed it: limbo or just get timed out

The lack of an Add Server button on consoles kneecaps the Bedrock dedicated server community and makes it difficult or impossible to run a server for people we actually know, since most active Bedrock players are on consoles at this point. As a PC Bedrock player trying to run a server, I'm often the weird guy in the corner raving about how great things are over here to people who can't experience it and have to put up with extremely underpowered realms to have persistent worlds, while unable to find anyone I know who can even use my server. Please please please, let us provide our own servers on our own hardware for our own friends.

Add this on every console please: it is such a good idea 

 

This would be a really good thing for the community: to let them play on custom servers, this option is already on tablet so why not have it on consoles?
We need this button plz mincraft it would only take you guys like 10 min and it would make our lives so much easier

Set up a couple of dedicated Minecraft BDS on an old server. Able to connect to the different worlds via the ports. This can be done on PC and Android but NOT on Series X.

Really disappointing to not have this capability across all environments.

We need the ability to add servers on consoles and anything about needing to maintain control over quality or privacy concerns is pure BS. This is nothing more than a money grab for realms and it's ridiculous. I have some custom hacks to help my users get around this but it's not worth the time anymore so I will be having to close down my servers and write parents letters explaining why I am closing down all my servers.

Plz add a add server button for bedrock

This needs to happen. It would be especially helpful for those building communities and that are capable of running their own dedicated servers. Having to leave a device logged into a world 24/7 just so others can join is not practical, because it pauses the world and does not allow others to join if the host has the game paused or running in the background. Playing your own world offers 8 player slots, and a realm only offers 10, so paying for a realm is not plausible at the extra cost. Especially when a dedicated server on a really good internet connection could easily handle 20+ players at one time.

PC users have a button in the Servers tab to "Add Server", and it should be present on all devices/consoles. This suggestion is three years old at this point and is becoming more and more relevant for many players in this era, but not enough people know to come here to make suggestions like this.

Developers can use the same concept for this as is available to PC users at no additional impact other than making it noted to users on certain devices if their device is not compatible with the add-ons included on that dedicated server.
I like that idea
They have not found a solution yet?
Yes this is a serious thing..
This needs to happen.
I just tried looking up how to do this. I'm really surprised there's no solution.
I think this should had been done long ago. You cannot depend on the same people keep on playing, but the community remains ...

Yes! We used to have a realm in a friends ownership and he stopped paying for it and stopped playing all together, he has the world saved and copied but we need a way to transfer ownership to one of us! This would be amazing to have and a real life saver, im sure everyone thats played on a realm that isnt theirs knows that after spending hours upon hours playing with friends is a real bummer when the server shuts down :(

This is a pretty old post, and it's surprising that Bedrock Edition still doesn't support RCON or offer any comparable remote interface. While it's not essential, it would definitely be a nice addition for server admins who want to automate tasks or manage their servers more efficiently — especially when running multiple instances.

This needs to happen. It would be especially helpful for those building communities and that are capable of running their own dedicated servers. Having to leave a device logged into a world 24/7 just so others can join is not practical, because it pauses the world and does not allow others to join if the host has the game paused or running in the background. Playing your own world offers 8 player slots, and a realm only offers 10, so paying for a realm is not plausible at the extra cost. Especially when a dedicated server on a really good internet connection could easily handle 20+ players at one time.

PC users have a button in the Servers tab to "Add Server", and it should be present on all devices/consoles. This suggestion is three years old at this point and is becoming more and more relevant for many players in this era, but not enough people know to come here to make suggestions like this.

Developers can use the same concept for this as is available to PC users at no additional impact other than making it noted to users on certain devices if their device is not compatible with the add-ons included on that dedicated server.
